[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-faucet/core/src/server/run.rs] [Function: get_run_config()] [Configuration Injection] Can an attacker provide a malicious YAML config file with deeply nested structures to cause stack overflow or excessive memory consumption during serde_yaml parsing, leading to denial of service? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-faucet/core/src/server/run.rs] [Struct: RunConfig] [Path Traversal] In get_run_config(), can an attacker use path traversal sequences (../, symlinks) in config_path to read arbitrary files from the filesystem, potentially exposing private keys or sensitive configuration? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-faucet/core/src/server/run.rs] [Struct: HandlerConfig] [Integer Overflow] Can max_concurrent_requests be set to usize::MAX causing integer overflow when creating the Semaphore, potentially bypassing concurrency limits and exhausting server resources? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-faucet/core/src/server/run.rs] [Function: get_run_config()] [Deserialization Attack] Does serde_yaml deserialization properly validate all config fields, or can malformed YAML trigger unsafe deserialization leading to arbitrary code execution or memory corruption? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-faucet/core/src/server/run.rs] [Struct: HandlerConfig] [Logic Bomb] Can use_helpful_errors be weaponized to expose sensitive internal state or error messages that reveal system architecture for reconnaissance? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-faucet/core/src/server/run.rs] [Function: run_impl()] [Cryptographic Key Exposure] During funder.build() at line 100-103, are private keys loaded into memory securely, or can they be exposed through core dumps, swap files, or memory inspection? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-faucet/core/src/server/run.rs] [Function: build_for_cli()] [Key File Security] At lines 261-264, when FunderKeyEnum::KeyFile is used, can an attacker perform TOCTOU (time-of-check-time-of-use) attacks by replacing the key file between validation and loading? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-faucet/core/src/server/run.rs] [Function: build_for_cli()] [Dummy Path Injection] At line 263, a dummy path '/dummy' is created for in-memory keys - can this create filesystem confusion or path resolution vulnerabilities in downstream code? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-faucet/core/src/server/run.rs] [Function: build_for_cli()] [Key Material Leakage] Are Ed25519PrivateKey instances properly zeroized after use, or do they persist in memory where they could be extracted through memory dumps or debugging? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-faucet/core/src/server/run.rs] [Struct: MintFunderConfig] [Privilege Escalation] At line 299, mint_account_address defaults to aptos_test_root_address() - can an attacker exploit misconfigured production deployments using test root address to gain unlimited minting privileges? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-faucet/core/src/server/run.rs] [Function: run_impl()] [Race Condition] At lines 93-96, the concurrent_requests_semaphore is created and cloned multiple times - can race conditions during concurrent access lead to permit leaks where semaphore permits are never released? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-faucet/core/src/server/run.rs] [Struct: BasicApi] [Semaphore Exhaustion] If max_concurrent_requests is set too low, can an attacker deliberately hold semaphore permits (slow client attacks) to starve legitimate users from accessing the faucet? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-faucet/core/src/server/run.rs] [Struct: FundApiComponents] [Deadlock] At line 151, concurrent_requests_semaphore is shared across multiple API components - can circular wait conditions arise where multiple components wait for each other's semaphore releases? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-faucet/core/src/server/run.rs] [Function: run_impl()] [Permit Leak] If an async task panics or is aborted while holding a semaphore permit, is the permit properly released, or does it permanently reduce available capacity? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-faucet/core/src/server/run.rs] [Function: run_impl()] [Bypasser Logic Bypass] At lines 115-121, bypassers are built from untrusted config - can an attacker craft a malicious BypasserConfig that always returns true, effectively disabling all security checkers? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-faucet/core/src/server/run.rs] [Function: run_impl()] [Checker Ordering Attack] At lines 142-143, checkers are sorted by cost - can an attacker exploit the ordering to ensure expensive checkers run first, causing DoS even for obviously invalid requests? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-faucet/core/src/server/run.rs] [Function: run_impl()] [Auth Token Forgery] When building bypassers at line 117, if auth token validation is weak, can attackers brute-force or forge tokens to bypass all rate limits and checker restrictions? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-faucet/core/src/server/run.rs] [Function: run_impl()] [Checker Build Failure] At lines 130-136, checker building can fail - is the error handling robust, or can partial checker initialization leave the faucet in an insecure state with missing protections? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-faucet/core/src/server/run.rs] [Struct: FundApiComponents] [Bypasser Priority] If multiple bypassers are configured, which one takes precedence, and can an attacker exploit ordering to use a weaker bypasser to circumvent stronger ones? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-faucet/core/src/server/run.rs] [Function: run_impl()] [Checker State Corruption] At line 137, checkers spawn periodic tasks - if these tasks crash or encounter errors, can it corrupt checker state leading to bypassing of security checks? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-faucet/core/src/server/run.rs] [Function: run_impl()] [Captcha Race Condition] At line 112, CaptchaManager is wrapped in Arc<Mutex> - can race conditions allow multiple requests to solve the same captcha, enabling captcha reuse attacks? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-faucet/core/src/server/run.rs] [Struct: CaptchaApi] [Captcha Bypass] At lines 159-165, tap_captcha_api_enabled flag is determined by config - can an attacker modify config to disable captcha entirely while keeping the API endpoint active? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-faucet/core/src/server/run.rs] [Function: run_impl()] [Captcha Token Leak] If CaptchaManager generates predictable tokens or doesn't properly invalidate them after use, can attackers reuse or predict captcha solutions? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-faucet/core/src/server/run.rs] [Struct: CaptchaApi] [State Inconsistency] The captcha_manager is shared between multiple API instances - can concurrent modifications lead to inconsistent state where captchas are marked as both solved and unsolved? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-faucet/core/src/server/run.rs] [Function: run_impl()] [CORS Misconfiguration] At lines 175-180, CORS allows credentials and all origins - can this enable cross-site request forgery attacks where malicious sites drain faucet funds on behalf of users? (Critical)
